heading: Virtual Solutions for Depression and Anxiety Toolkit

sections.heading: Performance-Based Contracting Toolkit: Virtual Solutions for Depression and Anxiety

steps.description:
This toolkit focuses on virtual solutions for depression and anxiety, drawing on findings from PHTI's Virtual Solutions for Depression and Anxiety Health Technology Assessment and PHTI's Performance-Based Contracting Playbook.

What this toolkit does:

Helps purchasers and digital health vendors establish clear, evidence-based contract terms that align payment with improvements in access to behavioral health services and related outcomes.

First, you will determine the design of the payment model. Next, you will determine the inputs for outcome measures, which include eligibility criteria, meaningful engagement criteria, and performance metrics. Finally, you will select operational components, which include engagement approach, data sharing commitments, and administrative terms, to include in your contracts.

A few notes before you continue:

  • This toolkit helps you navigate key contracting decisions for performance-based contracts. It does not create a binding legal contract.
  • These toolkits do not address pricing—a critical lever for driving impact in performance-based contracts. Purchasers and vendors are encouraged to consult PHTI’s assessment reports and budget impact models as resources to guide pricing conversations.
  • Toolkit responses are anonymous. We do not gather or store any data about you, your organization, or your selections.

The content of this playbook/report and its associated toolkits has been prepared by PHTI for informational purposes and does not constitute legal, medical, clinical or other professional advice. PHTI cannot make any guarantees or warranties regarding results from the use of such content. The content is not intended to replace thoughtful customization and drafting addressing an organization’s specific objectives and circumstances. All companies, specific products or case studies mentioned are for explanatory purposes only.

Prefer to skip the interactive toolkit? Download the virtual solutions for depression and anxiety toolkit with PHTI's recommended selections.
steps.descriptionPdf:
PHTI’s performance-based contracting toolkits help purchasers and vendors negotiate contracts that link payment to verified outcomes, based on PHTI's independent evaluation and research.

This toolkit focuses on virtual solutions for depression and anxiety, drawing on findings from PHTI's Virtual Solutions for Depression and Anxiety Health Technology Assessment and PHTI's Performance-Based Contracting Playbook. It is meant to help purchasers and vendors establish clear, evidence-based contract terms that align payment with improvements in access to behavioral health services and related outcomes.

The content of this playbook/report and its associated toolkits has been prepared by PHTI for informational purposes and does not constitute legal, medical, clinical or other professional advice. PHTI cannot make any guarantees or warranties regarding results from the use of such content. The content is not intended to replace thoughtful customization and drafting addressing an organization’s specific objectives and circumstances. All companies, specific products or case studies mentioned are for explanatory purposes only.

tooltipDrawer.label: Learn more about payment models.
tooltipDrawer.text:
About Payment Models

A performance-based contract structures your payments to reward outcomes while minimizing administrative burden, avoiding perverse incentives, and balancing accountability with budget predictability.

steps.heading: Select the payment model(s) for the contract.
steps.description:
While PHTI generally recommends tying performance payments to validated clinical outcomes in most clinical areas, purchasers of depression and anxiety solutions often prioritize expanding access to care and driving sustained engagement. Interviews indicate that purchasers view engagement as a critical early indicator of performance and a necessary precursor to downstream clinical improvement and cost impact. As a result, many purchasers structure payment models that emphasize engagement-based payments—moving away from flat PMPM arrangements that pay regardless of utilization—while selectively incorporating clinical outcome–based performance payments as programs mature and measurement infrastructure strengthens.

Review details of each payment model. PHTI recommends tying a majority of contract value to engagement-based payments to incentivize broad access.

Recommended values are pre-filled. Percentages must sum to 100%.
steps.note:
Contracting tip:
  • If including a cap on sessions, specify patient options once cap is reached, e.g., transitioning to other network care or out of pocket payment.
  • Purchasers may select a monthly or quarterly case rate model as opposed to a per visit fee.

tooltip.text: Monthly payment for each member meeting “Meaningful Engagement” (see section 3 - Engagement Criteria). PEMPM pricing includes access to self-guided digital content.
Standard session fee charged per virtual live visit, up to a monthly and/or annual cap per member.
Single payment for a bundle of multiple virtual live visits.

Additional payment based on achievement of selected clinical performance measure(s); often used selectively in depression and anxiety contracts alongside engagement-based payments (see section 4 - Performance metrics).

tooltipDrawer.label: About eligible population.
tooltipDrawer.text:
About Eligibility Population

Eligibility criteria determine which plan members may engage with the solution and have their outcomes measured. Eligibility typically includes clinical criteria, demographics, or utilization history.

The inclusion and exclusion criteria define the total population of eligible members who may engage with the solution. Narrowing the eligibility will limit the number of individuals who may be included in the denominator and the numerator.

Contracting tip:

  • Include clause allowing digital health solution vendor to update the exclusion criteria based on medical contraindications. (e.g., Serious Mental Illness (SMI) and associated medications).
  • Specify timing for when exclusion criteria adjustments can be made to the contract.
  • Consider tiered pricing for lower acuity patients being treated with lower intensity intervention. Add data sharing commitments to ensure transparency of triage process.

steps.heading: Payment Model Inputs
steps.description:
The following section details the inputs required to define the eligible population and calculate outcomes measures. The selections for each of these components will impact the threshold for PEMPM payments as well as the equation for calculating performance withholds.

Performance Payment Calculation:

  • Numerator: For cohort in the denominator, number of eligible members who meet the performance threshold for the measure of interest.
  • Denominator: Total eligible members who meet the meaningful engagement definition for duration of program tenure requirement.

steps.heading: Select the members eligible to use the solution.

tooltipDrawer.label: About engagement criteria.
tooltipDrawer.text:
Clear, meaningful engagement thresholds help limit payment to members who are meaningfully engaged with the solution and most likely to experience a clinical impact. While there are many common engagement metrics, not all are considered meaningful.

In the two-payment stream model, the definition of meaningful engagement directly impacts the size of the payments made to the vendor. A looser definition of engagement will create a larger PEMPM payment and will increase the number of individuals whose clinical outcomes are considered for the performance payment.

Contracting tip:

  • At least one of the above interactions must be member-initiated (e.g., scheduling appointment, messaging, starting a module); however, consider excluding therapy sessions from member-initiated requirement to allow provider to follow up with appointment scheduling without penalty.
  • Define the maximum days (e.g., 15) for capturing baseline clinical measures, considering operational workflows.

steps.heading: Define engagement criteria for the contract.
steps.description:
Currently the main definitions of engagement in use today include metrics such as app logins, email opens, and an engagement index. Purchasers increasingly indicate that they prefer more meaningful engagement metrics, especially as these metrics serve as the basis for PEMPM payments and performance payment calculations. PHTI’s recommended definitions focus on engagement milestones that are correlated with clinical impact.

PHTI recommends members meet 3 criteria to be considered meaningfully engaged. Criteria 1 and 2 are required.

Recommended values are pre-filled.

options.label: Criteria 1: Member completes onboarding, initial assessment, or first visit.

tooltip.text: Engagement tied to clinician interaction, including sessions, coaching calls, messages.

options.label: Criteria 2: Baseline clinical assessment (first month only).
Must complete a validated screening tool within __ days of enrollment
Criteria 3: Member must meet at least <u>one</u> of the following interaction thresholds each month.

tooltip.text: Meaningful Engagement Criteria informed by PHTI Virtual Solutions for Depression and Anxiety Health Technology Assessment based on the various care models studied.

options.label: Live therapy or coaching session: ≥ __ sessions completed
Two-way asynchronous messaging with care team: ≥ __ exchanges

tooltipDrawer.label: About performance metrics.
tooltipDrawer.text:
Select validated, feasible measures—favoring biomarker-based outcomes and clinically accepted instruments—and determine the time horizon for impact.

Contracting tip:

  • Define appropriate administration pathway for assessment (e.g., administered by a trained clinician or, when self-reported, completed independently by patients using a validated survey tool) and establish data collection standards to maintain inter-rater reliability.

steps.heading: Select which performance metric(s) should be tied to the performance payment.
steps.description:
In depression and anxiety contracts, many purchasers emphasize engagement-based performance as the primary lever, reflecting the importance of access to care and sustained participation as prerequisites to meaningful clinical improvement. Engagement is often viewed as a more immediate and attributable indicator of performance within typical contract periods.

Some purchasers also incorporate downstream clinical outcome–based performance payments, particularly as programs mature, to reinforce accountability for symptom improvement. Where clinical performance measures are included, PHTI recommends using validated, widely adopted instruments with established benchmarks.

Recommended values are pre-filled.

options.label: Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9): Validated assessment containing nine questions that assesses frequency of symptoms in the previous two weeks, such as low mood, fatigue, sleep disturbances, and thoughts of self-harm. Each item is scored from 0 to 3, yielding a total score between 0 and 27, with higher scores representing more severe symptoms.

Generalized Anxiety Disorder scale-7 (GAD-7): Validated assessment containing seven questions that measure indicators of generalized anxiety, such as excessive worry, restlessness, and difficulty relaxing, resulting in scores ranging from 0 to 21.

steps.heading: Confirm desired program tenure for inclusion in the performance payment.
steps.description:
Improvement in PHQ-9 and GAD-7 can be expected to yield results within 6-12 weeks as demonstrated in PHTI's Virtual Solutions for Depression and Anxiety Health Technology Assessment. PHTI recommends 16 weeks (4 months) to account for potential scheduling delays.

Recommended values are pre-filled.

tooltipDrawer.label: About engagement approaches.
tooltipDrawer.text:
Engagement approaches establish clear parameters for how vendors may contact and interact with members to promote engagement with the solution.

Purchasers may seek to limit outreach frequency, require member consent or opt-in, and specify permissible channels (e.g., text, phone, mailer) to protect member trust and prevent over communication. Vendors value flexibility to reach members through multiple touch points and may need to tailor outreach strategies to different populations. This repeated, multimodal contact can be important to drive engagement and outcomes for some solutions.

steps.heading: Select your engagement approach.
steps.description:
The following section details the operational components of the contract that are critical to successful implementation of performance-based contracts.

Recommended values are pre-filled.

options.label: Governance Alignment: Vendor will adhere to the purchaser’s existing governance processes for member communications (e.g., prior review committees, compliance protocols) and will not initiate outreach outside of those processes without written approval.

Material Review & Approval: Vendor will submit all co-branded and company-branded outreach and education materials for purchaser approval prior to use (co-branded materials are generally preferred and shown to improve engagement). Purchaser will approve or propose modifications within __ days of submission.

Revisions & Updates: Any revisions to previously approved materials (including templates, scripts, and digital content) must be resubmitted for purchaser review and approval within __ days before deployment.

Outreach Parameters: Purchaser and vendor will agree in advance on the minimum or maximum number, frequency, and type of outreach attempts (e.g., SMS, email, phone) to optimize engagement while minimizing member abrasion. Any deviation requires prior purchaser approval.
Compliance & Reporting: Vendor will track all member outreach against agreed guidelines and share reporting (frequency, channel, response rates, opt-outs) with the purchaser at agreed intervals.

Member Experience Protections: Outreach must comply with applicable laws and regulations (e.g., TCPA, HIPAA) and avoid high-frequency or intrusive tactics. Vendor will promptly address purchaser concerns about member complaints or abrasion.

tooltipDrawer.label: About data sharing commitments.
tooltipDrawer.text:
Reliable performance measurement is foundational to performance-based contracting. To assess whether a solution is driving clinical or financial impact, purchasers and vendors need access to timely, high-quality data and the analytic capacity to interpret them in a timely manner.

Contracting tip:

  • For all data file sharing, determine cadence and format for sharing prior to contracting. Consider including template reports in the contract to ensure file readability.
  • Purchasers commit to active list management, including monthly deletions, corrections, and additions.
  • Purchaser submits monthly list in machine readable format with members that meet eligibility criteria. Eligibility file should include full population to avoid claims lag post-diagnosis. Pre-determine select data fields to include in the file (e.g., plan ID, name, address, demographics).
  • Include purchaser audit rights for vendor data in contract.

steps.heading: Select which data sharing commitments should be included in the contract.

fields.label: From Purchaser to Vendor: Data sharing format
From Vendor to Purchaser: Data sharing format

options.label: Summary statistics on all enrolled and engaged members:
No show rate for live sessions
Session utilization e.g., average number of live sessions utilized per member

tooltip.text: Such as access metrics stratified by preferred language (time to first appointment for Spanish speakers vs. English speakers).
Such as measures proximate to enrollment and last measurement of the performance period such as PHQ-9/GAD-7.
For members excluded for clinical reasons, share report of documented reasons.

options.label: Data required to feed into data warehouse/third party data management resource

tooltipDrawer.label: About administrative terms.
tooltipDrawer.text:
Contracting tip:

  • Require a minimum number of meaningfully engaged patients to trigger performance payment. If minimum is not met, suggest no performance payment.

steps.heading: Select Administrative Terms: Reconciliation
steps.description:
The timeline required to observe meaningful improvements in clinical outcomes or reductions in total cost of care frequently exceeds the duration of most purchaser-vendor contracts.

Purchasers should consider availability of resources required to calculate performance payments prior to establishing bonus determination deadline.

Recommended values are pre-filled.

options.label: One year measurement period, beginning when minimum enrollment is achieved for __ months

tooltip.text: Improvement in PHQ-9 and GAD-7 can be expected to yield results within 6-12 weeks as demonstrated in PHTI's Virtual Solutions for Depression and Anxiety Health Technology Assessment. PHTI recommends 16 weeks (4 months) to account for potential scheduling delays.
Populated based on minimum program tenure selection in Decision 4: Performance Metrics.

options.label: Bonuses determined within a __ month period following __ months post-measurement period

tooltip.text: Suggest 3 months to ensure time for claims run-out.

steps.heading: Select Administrative Terms: Duration and Renewal

options.label: __-year initial term, with fixed price throughout term

tooltip.text:
Cause for termination may include:

  • Lack of critical mass of members meeting meaningful engagement criteria.
  • Lack of critical mass of members meeting program tenure for performance payment eligibility.

options.label: Billing Frequency
options.note: Most purchasers will elect quarterly PEMPM and utilization payments and annual performance payments. In cases where high churn exists among members, purchasers may prefer to reconcile performance payments on a quarterly basis.

options.label: Per engaged member per month (PEMPM) payments billing frequency
